doc.title: Zhejiang Dingli Co Ltd. (603338. SS): NDR takeaways: Improving cyclical outlook reaffirmed; price negotiation likely; Buy
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/Zhejiang Dingli Co Ltd. 603338.SS NDR takeaways Improving cyclical outlook reaffirmed price negotiation likely Buy Zheji_2025-08-29

passages.text: We hosted an NDR group call with Dingli management on Aug 28 post its 2Q25 results (see our first take note). On the call, management highlighted CMEC's resilient US sales in 1H25 (flat yoy) despite US- China tariff escalation in April, robust growth in non- US/Europe markets (primarily EMs) and revived growth from small- to- medium- sized domestic rental customers. Into 2H, EU could also turn from a headwind into tailwind given the low base and gradual cyclically recovery. Dingli is currently bearing the additional tariff announced this year in the US but mentioned price negotiation for next year will likely happen towards the year- end once more clarity on US tariff comes out. We maintain our Buy rating with an unchanged 12- m TP of Rmb64.0 after fine- tuning our earnings estimates post 2Q25 results.
Overseas sales (+21% yoy in 1H25):

For US sales, management said CMEC managed to achieve stable yoy sales in 1H25 despite a 1\~2 months temporarily suspended US shipment in Apr/May due to the US tariff escalation. Management mentioned that, despite the sufficient overall inventory prepared in the US, given the wide range of product SKUs Dingli offers, the products that customers take at a given time are not necessarily in stock.

Regarding EU sales, management said 1H25 was relatively soft due to a high comparison base last year, as the shipments to EU last year were front loaded in 1H ahead of the anticipated announcement of EU anti- dumping rulings in June.

For non- Europe/US markets (mainly EMs), management highlighted robust growth (DD% yoy) in 1H25 on accelerated market penetration and expanded market coverage, with sales contribution rising to 25% of total sales.

Domestig sales (c.- 30% yoy decline in 1H25 based on GSe): management said that the decline was mainly due to weak sales from large- sized rental customers, who have significantly slowed the pace of procurement this year. That said, management highlighted the revived growth from

Goldman Sachs does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. For Reg AC certification and other important disclosures, see the Disclosure Appendix, or go to www.gs.com/research/hedge.html. Analysts employed by non- US affiliates are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA in the U.S.
small- to- medium sized customers (sales were up \(+20\%\) yoy in 1H25) which now contributes \(25\%\) of total domestic sales.

Management attributed the GPM decline (- 0.8ppt yoy) in 2Q25 mainly to product mix change with increasing sales from boom lifts sales (blended GPM still below scissors at the moment), coupled with the impact of higher US tariff and the imposition of EU anti- dumping duties.
US tariff and anti- dumping duties:

Management said Dingli's current tariff and duties in US now was \(79\%\) ( \(24\%\) anti- dumping/subsidy duties and \(55\%\) tariffs, details see our analysis note here), c. 10ppt higher than last year's level. Management said Dingli has no intention to pass on the additional tariff within this year, but may consider renewing the price for next year's sales during 2H25 contract negotiation if tariff remained at current high level. Regarding the Section 232 tariff (AWP products are included in the list), management said the impact is limited as steel and aluminum content account for a very small portion of an AWP.

EU duties: management highlighted Dingli now has the lowest anti- dumping/subsidy duties in this region compared to peers (2\~15ppt lower than overseas peers', and 20\~30ppt lower than domestic peers), and said that 1H25 has seen market share gain helped by relatively favorable duties. Regarding the ASP, management said Dingli has managed to pass on parts of duties to customers, with the split varied by customers.

US market: management said AWP demand was solid up to now based on the feedback from CMEC, and highlighted Dingli's differentiated product offering has continued to gain momentum. Management reiterated the company's guidance on CMEC (i.e., flat sales yoy in 2025E). The current inventory level in the US could support the company's sales till year- end.

EU market: management said the market demand was relatively soft compared to other regions, but noted sustained demand for electrification and high- end products where Dingli holds more competitive advantages. Management expects 2H25 sales to see yoy improvement off low comparison base last year coupled with sales ramp- up of high- end new products and expects full- year sales to see positive growth yoy.
Regarding overseas capacity expansion, management said the company has prepared relevant plans and will make the decisions based on the tariff changes.

Zhejiang Dingli is one of China's largest suppliers of aerial working platforms (AWP), a type of powered access equipment used in building construction, maintenance, cleaning, utilities and events. Our Buy rating on the stock is based on 1) long- term adoption potential of AWPs in China (a significantly under- penetrated market from a global context) driven by rising labor wages (against falling rental rates for AWPs), a construction worker shortage, and increasing safety awareness; 2) product mix upgrade towards higher- ASP and higher- barrier- to- entry boom lifts (vs. scissor lifts) where Dingli has built a substantial technology gap vs. domestic peers while leading the \(22m+\) boom electrification technology globally; and 3) growing competitiveness in the overseas markets driven by product differentiation (electrification in particular).

Dingli remains well positioned within our China Industrials coverage with a proven track record of maintaining operational resilience under a high- tariff/duty environment; e.g. has navigated two complete rounds of targeted trade restrictions (on AWPs) by the US and EU, which in our view has significantly optimized the competitive landscape by limiting competition from (or raising the bar for) Chinese peer exporters. We view this as a strong testament to its product differentiation (leading to pricing power) and cost competitiveness enabled by a high level of vertical integration and superior supply chain management.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
